_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: 29CFR1910.111 used as applicable in the ammonia conversion process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR 2745.3)


ES1.0 | FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of Dixon Wholesale, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Dixon Facility or Facility) at 7235 Tremont Road, Dixon, California 95620 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response Plan (ERP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release. The Dixon Facility carries the US EPA Facility Identifier number 100-000-028793.


ES2.0 | FACILITY INFORMATION
The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers) and 325311 (Nitrogenous Fertilizer Manufacturing).

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA
*-Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is received, converted, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 

*-Anhydrous ammonia is converted to aqua ammonia (ammonium hydroxide) and reacted with super phosphoric acid (SPA) to produce ammonium phosphate [10-34-0] fertilizer).

*-Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in either an 18,000-gallon storage tank (bullet) or a 30,050-gallon storage tank.

*-The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 

= > Bullet 1 | 18,000 gals (Cap.); 15,300 gals (Max. amt); 78,642 lbs (Mass NH3)

= > Bullet 2 | 30,050 gals (Cap.); 25,542 gals (Max. amt); 131,286 lbs (Mass NH3)

= > Totals | 48,050 gals (Cap.); 40,842 gals (Max. amt); 209,928 lbs (Mass

NH3)

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 209,928 pounds.
~~~~~
AQUA AMMONIA
*-Aqua ammonia is produced from anhydrous ammonia and stored in a 10,000-gallon storage tank and a 25,000-gallon storage tank. 

*-The aqua ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 90% of shell volume. 

= > Tank 24 | 25k gals (Cap.); 22.5k gals (Max. amt); 171k lbs (Mass aqua); 41,625 lbs (Mass NH3)

= > Tank 25 | 10k gals (Cap.); 9k gals (Max. amt); 68.4k lbs (Mass aqua); 16,650 lbs (Mass NH3)

= > Totals | 35k gals	(Cap.); 31.5k gals (Max. amt); 239.4k lbs (Mass aqua); 58,275 lbs (Mass NH3)

The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia (24.3% solution) handled is 239,400 pounds. The maximum amount of ammonia (as NH3) in the aqua solution is 58,275 lbs.


ES3.0 | ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

SAFETY INFORMATION: 
The Facility ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees.

HAZARD REVIEW:
A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. A review of the results from the most recent hazard review update for the anhydrous ammonia process, aqua ammonia process, and pesticide handling and storage indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.

OPERATING PROCEDURES:
Written operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures are reviewed and recertified on an annual basis. Revisions and improvements occur as needed. 

TRAINING:
Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an esse

ntial element of an effective prevention program. The current training program is comprised of the following:
1. Initial employee training.
2. Periodic refresher training.
3. Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.
4. Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
5. Training records for each employee.

MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:
The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:
Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures.

PRE-START-UP SAFETY REVIEW:
The pre-start-up safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-start-up safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a pre-start-up safety review is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS:
Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written RMP must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:
Although no incidents inv

olving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:
The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. 

HOT WORK PERMIT:
With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Grow West has developed a written Hot Work Permit program and procedure to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. 

CONTRACTOR SAFETY:
The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. The Facility also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely.

OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:
The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):

Regulated Substances
 United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans. 
 United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency

Response.

Anhydrous Ammonia 
 United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.
 California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders.
 Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]

Anhydrous and Aqua Ammonia
 American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping.
 California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials.

Regulated Pesticides
 National Fire Protection Association and California Fire Code; and
 California Code of Regulations (Title 3. Food and Agriculture), Division 6. Pesticides and Pest Control Operations. 


ES4.0 | FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.


ES5.0 | THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facilitys emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The facility also developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations §2745.8. The ERP will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.


ES6.0 | PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and regulated pesticide processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.


ES7.0 | THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
ANHYDRO

US AMMONIA Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. 
The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 131,288 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the larger storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and D stability modeling parameters.

AQUA AMMONIA Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios.
The worst-case scenario is failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 41,625 pounds of aqua ammonia that forms a liquid pool. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a pipe break modeled with an increased wind speed and "D" Stability modeling parameters.
